description: The Querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014 show is for those who are seeking to validate their skills and knowledge in writing Transact SQL queries.  The show helps the certification candidate by describing, discussing and demonstrating SQL query writing skills in multiple areas. The episodes will cover the advanced SELECT statements, grouping sets, aggregates, SET operators, basic T-SQL programming and Performance Improvement.  The show focuses heavily on demonstrating the syntax and logic of writing the queries.  This particular exam is intended for candidates that have two or more years of experience in writing queries with Microsoft SQL Server
name: Microsoft SQL Server 2014 - 70-461
subtitle: Querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming Querying SQL series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:04.874
[SOUND] In this segment,
we're gonna give you

2
00:00:04.874 --> 00:00:09.596
a general overview on
our upcoming series on

3
00:00:09.596 --> 00:00:14.586
querying the Microsoft SQL server 2014.

4
00:00:14.586 --> 00:00:18.534
And Ronnie I'm glad you're here with me
today because I was hoping you could give

5

us a very good overview, at least
a general expectation of what we should,

6
00:00:22.193 --> 00:00:24.130
well expect, on the upcoming series.

7
00:00:24.130 --> 00:00:26.000
>> Sure that'd be a great way for

8
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:30.120
us to get started when we start

9

Now let's go ahead and take a look at

And that way that will help us to get

00:00:52.960 --> 00:00:57.580
the entire exam actually

2014 SQL server right

Now when it comes down to what we end up

is we're going to essentially cover all

So where we're gonna begin

at the database objects as well.

So we are going to make sure that we
understand how of course to create and

to understand those elements that we need

As well as create the idea of

Now, we also want to actually took

39

Okay and then we go into modifying our

When we start to create and of course

Which allows us, once again,
to be able to limit the access that

51

other people can have to our

And to make sure that the complex logic

do, is not gonna ever have to be exposed

54

Being able to build other objects inside

Now, the reason why I want to point that

65

66

But you do need to get your hands

67

69

The reason why is that you're

71

72

So understanding the syntax,
getting the muscle memory that you need to

73

involved is actually gonna
be very important for

74
00:04:25.559 --> 00:04:29.170
just about everything that we do for
the exam as well.

75
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:33.231
Now I do want us to make sure that we
understand there is a couple of things we

76

would consider prerequisites, when getting
ready for the exam, and so lets go and

77
00:04:37.816 --> 00:04:40.987
take a look at my page again and
this should help us out to.

78

Okay, so notice that it even says who
should actually take this exam here?

79

It says this exam is intended for
SQL Server database administrators,

80
00:04:50.750 --> 00:04:52.780
system engineers, and developers.

81
00:04:52.780 --> 00:04:57.020
And the key is right here at the end,
two or more years of experience

82

who are seeking to validate their
knowledge in of course in writing queries.

83
00:05:01.670 --> 00:05:03.620
Now this is actually very important.

84
00:05:03.620 --> 00:05:07.530
It doesn't mean that you cannot
take the exam any time you want to.

85
00:05:07.530 --> 00:05:10.430
Regardless of whether or
not you have the SQL experience or

86

not but
what it does mean is if you don't you're

87
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:17.020
going to be very confused by some of
the things that they're going to show you.

88

They're gonna implement of course
different scenarios that you might not be

89

familiar with if you're not working
with SQL pretty much on a daily basis.

90
00:05:25.180 --> 00:05:29.250
So do not expect as a beginner
here if you're just learning SQL

91

that this is the exam for you right away.

92
00:05:31.910 --> 00:05:36.820
You may wanna make sure that you ahead and
have the foundational concepts down and

93
00:05:36.820 --> 00:05:41.470
that you feel very comfortable in
writing at least basic SQL statements

94
00:05:41.470 --> 00:05:46.410
before you start actually on this as
a track that you may wish to follow.

95
00:05:46.410 --> 00:05:50.430
So it's very important that we do
that because a lot of times maybe

96
00:05:50.430 --> 00:05:54.540
you have this expectation that this
is a very much a fundamental exam.

97
00:05:54.540 --> 00:05:58.270
That you can jump right into it but you
gonna see challenges here that you may not

98

expect to see and you do not work
in SQL just about on a daily basis.

99
00:06:03.420 --> 00:06:10.045
Now overall though for the exam itself the
price in US dollars is about $150 here.

100
00:06:10.045 --> 00:06:12.950
So it does require you
to pay that exam fee.

101
00:06:12.950 --> 00:06:17.500
So you go to your
Pearson Vue testing center.

102
00:06:17.500 --> 00:06:19.700
And don't forget,
you do actually have to sign up for this.

103
00:06:19.700 --> 00:06:22.290
You can go online to make sure
you have your account, and

104
00:06:22.290 --> 00:06:26.560
that you pay the fee, and register
to the nearest Pearson Vue center,

105
00:06:26.560 --> 00:06:31.740
where you'll schedule a date and then you
will go in and take that exam as well.

106
00:06:31.740 --> 00:06:35.430
So, this particular exam even
though it may cover both of them

107
00:06:35.430 --> 00:06:38.200
everything that we'll cover
essentially works on both.

108
00:06:38.200 --> 00:06:43.110
And the other thing, if you are really
concerned about the idea that hey,

109
00:06:43.110 --> 00:06:45.090
2012 is different from 2014,

110
00:06:45.090 --> 00:06:50.550
you'll see that Microsoft itself,
in December 2015 here, okay?

111
00:06:50.550 --> 00:06:54.490
Evaluated that the exam didn't
need to be updated between both.

112
00:06:54.490 --> 00:06:57.570
So in other words, whatever you
actually learned on SQL Server 2012,

113
00:06:57.570 --> 00:07:00.980
if you've already been studying for
that you can jump right into this and

114
00:07:00.980 --> 00:07:03.760
this should also to continue
to help you out as well.

115
00:07:03.760 --> 00:07:05.840
So there's some details in it, but

116
00:07:05.840 --> 00:07:07.730
you actually see that
we'll cover a lot of them.

117
00:07:07.730 --> 00:07:11.760
And we actually make sure that we use
a bunch of examples as well to ensure that

118
00:07:11.760 --> 00:07:15.990
you actually have the most visuals that
you can and you'll actually be typing

119
00:07:15.990 --> 00:07:20.340
in SQL, just about, I want to say at least
50% of the content that we end up actually

120
00:07:20.340 --> 00:07:25.650
covering will end up being straight
examples that we end up using.

121
00:07:25.650 --> 00:07:28.960
So just make sure that you take the time,
go through that.

122
00:07:28.960 --> 00:07:31.430
And make sure you study
on your own as well.

123
00:07:31.430 --> 00:07:33.780
And that's really going to help you.

124
00:07:33.780 --> 00:07:37.330
If you're working towards
your SQL server MCSA.

125
00:07:37.330 --> 00:07:39.870
>> All right, Ronnie well thank you so
much for that overview, it was great.

126
00:07:39.870 --> 00:07:43.750
And hopefully if that's something that
sounds like that you might be interested

127
00:07:43.750 --> 00:07:47.687
in or that you need to prepare for to get
that actual exam certification underneath

128
00:07:47.687 --> 00:07:50.960
your belt, we look forward to seeing
you in the upcoming episodes.

129
00:07:50.960 --> 00:07:58.391
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie begin their discussion of querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014. Here they begin at the beginning; going over the basics of MS SQL Server 2014 editions as well as a primer on SQL databases in general, including terms you should be familiar with.
episodes.title: SQL Server Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie come back to finish up their discussion and primer of working with the Microsoft SQL Server 2014 Management interface. They also discuss the different default databases you'll encounter after installation, which includes the System Databases (Master, MSDB, Model, TempDB) and User created databases.
episodes.title: SQL Server Basics Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie look into the basics of SQL querying. They start by defining what SQL is and how it differs from Transact SQL. They also explain the 3 categories of T-SQL statements which are Data Manipulation Language (DML), Data Definition Language(DDL), and Data Control Language(DCL). Finally, they explain the Key-In Order vs. the Processing Order.
episodes.title: SQL Querying Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie discuss table creation with T-SQL. They talk about T-SQL syntax and demonstrate how to create, alter and compress tables. They look at querying information from existing tables to new tables.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Tables

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie explain how to restrict the information presented to a user or application by creating views. They also demonstrate how to the a view that has already been created.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Views

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on restricting the information presented to users or applications. They using the inline table-valued function as well as creating indexed views to optimize performance. They also talk about how to ensure that the database doesn’t break.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Views Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on creating and altering views with querying Microsoft SQL Server 2014. They discuss topics like ensuring code non-regression and data validation.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Views Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie take a look a ways to maintain consistency within a database by using constraints. They discuss primary key constraints with demonstrations on how to implement them. They will also explore using foreign key constraints while demonstrating their implementation.
episodes.title: Create and Modify Constraints

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Ronnie continue their discussion on maintaining consistency within a database using constraints. They look at unique constraints and demonstrate how they should be implemented as well as diving into the using default constraints.
episodes.title: Create and Modify Constraints Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to create and alter DML Triggers in SQL 2014. The start by explaining the particulars of DML Triggers; the when/where/why/how they are used. Then they take a look at the AFTER trigger type followed by the INSTEAD OF trigger type. Finally, they explore nested triggers and how to use the UPDATE function.
episodes.title: Create and Alter DML Triggers

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie start their exposition of the SELECT SQL query. They start by showing you how to perform a simple SELECT query to find set data from a database. Then they pair down the results by using the WHERE and GROUP BY filter statements.
episodes.title: Basic SELECT Queries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their exposition of the SELECT SQL query. They begin by showing you how to perform a SELECT query to filter grouped data and then filter even more by removing duplicate results. Finally, they introduce you to some decision making features of SQL by employing the CASE command.
episodes.title: Basic SELECT Queries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe how to use the JOINs function to return data from multiple databases. They begin by looking at the traditional way to query data from multiple databases and then how to use the INNER JOIN command to filter that data down. Then they show you the LEFT JOIN and RIGHT JOIN commands to return data sets that have matching values as well as all values from either the right or left tables respectively.
episodes.title: Query Using JOINS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and use of Temporary Tables, Views, and Derived Tables. They start by showing you how to use the Temporary Tables and Views and while both can be beneficial, also have their problems. Then they jump into the use of Derived Tables which are more efficient than using Temp Tables.
episodes.title: Query Using JOINS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain and implement 3 different types of Subqueries in SQL. They start off with the Scalar subquery, which is used to return a single value result. Next they look at the Multi-Valued subquery, which is used to return multiple results. Finally they test your logical aptitude with Correlated Subqueries which works together with the outer query.
episodes.title: Implement Subqueries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue to examine the use of Subqueries in SQL. Here specifically they look at Pivoting and Un-Pivoting tables. Pivots will allow you to modify the returned data to turning row data into columns for easier viewing. Un-Pivot will be the reformatting of pivoted data back to normal.
episodes.title: Implement Subqueries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look into Subqueries in SQL. They start off by exploring the use of the APPLY operator, which is a replacement for correlated subqueries and derived tables. Finally they demonstrate using a Common Table Expression(CTE).
episodes.title: Implement Subqueries Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain the concept and different implementations of aggregate queries. They start by taking a look at GROUPING SETS which will define the groups. Next they explore the CUBE statement which creates every possible group. Finally, they explain the ROLLUP statement which will create a group with a hierarchy.
episodes.title: Implement Aggregate Queries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their discussion on aggregate queries, picking up by looking at the use of the RANK() function, which assigns a value to data for sorting purposes. They also show you how to add row numbers and even grouping data by percentile using the NTILE() function.
episodes.title: Implement Aggregate Queries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look at aggregate queries by discussing Spatial Aggregates. Spatial aggregates allow you to visualize data by using a map(Geographical) or a shape(Geometrical). They walk you through the 4 Spatial Aggregate types including: Union, Envelope, Collection, and Convex.
episodes.title: Implement Aggregate Queries Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to query SQL Server 2014 using Synonyms, Intersects, and Excepts. They start by looking at the Synonyms, which are similar to Aliases, but are more permanent. Next they describe the use of the Intersect which returns distinct rows that are common between sets. Finally, they explore the Except which returns distinct rows that are in the first query but not the second.
episodes.title: Query Using Synonyms, Except and Intersect

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at the different Data Access technologies. They start by explaining what Data Access technologies are and how they're used. This includes DA's like SQL Server Native Client(SNAC), ADO.NET, JDBC drivers, and Microsoft drivers for PHP.
episodes.title: Understand Data Access Technologies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to work with conditional statements and NULL values. They begin by explaining the CASE function to perform decisions based on matching conditions. They then turn to the IS NULL function to test for NULL values. Finally, they explain how to use the COALESCE function to replace a NULL value with another value.
episodes.title: Work with Conditions and Nulls

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain how to work with table constraints. They start by using the INSERT INTO function to select data from one table and insert it into an existing table. Then they use INSERT to create a new table. Finally, they show you how to use the VALUES function.
episodes.title: Work with Table Constraints

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to query and manage XML data in a SQL 2014 database. They start by explaining the when and why you would be working with XML and then show you how to create XML data from relational data.
episodes.title: Query and Manage XML Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their look at querying and managing XML data in SQL 2014. Here they introduce you to the practice of "shredding" XML into tables. Finally, they explain the process of XML indexing; creating and using both primary and secondary indexes.
episodes.title: Query and Manage XML Data Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Ronnie discuss the different data types that any administrator should know and understand when planning database structure. They explain numeric, exact and approximate data types. They show the data and time data types and their characteristics.
episodes.title: Implement Data Types

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explain using Stored Procedures in SQL 2014. They begin by introducing you to stored procedures; what they are and why they are used. Then they show you how to create a simple stored procedure utilizing both input and output parameters. Finally they go over Branching Logic controls used as conditional elements.
episodes.title: Create and Alter Stored Procedures

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore using the INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements in SQL Server 2014. Here they look at INSERT to insert one or more rows into a target table. They show how this can be done with single values as well as multiple values. They also demonstrate using the INSERT SELECT and EXEC statements.
episodes.title: INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue their discussion of INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE statements in SQL Server 2014. They pick back up with the SELECT INTO statement and then jump into the UPDATE statement, explaining both ideas of deterministic and nondeterministic. Finally, they demonstrate deleting data using the DELETE statement.
episodes.title: INSERT, UPDATE and DELETE Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie demonstrate how to combine datasets. They go over the difference between UNION and UNION ALL and the rules that govern their use. They also look at modifying data with MERGE statements.
episodes.title: Combine Datasets

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie show you how to create and work with functions. They explain what functions in SQL are and look at the two types of User Defined Functions(UDFs), Scalar and Table-Valued, giving examples of each.
episodes.title: Work with Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce you to optimization queries. They begin by explaining the 5 query execution phases. Next, they go over the two types of statistics, TIME and IO, giving examples of both.
episodes.title: Optimize Queries

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue exploring query optimization. They look into the Execution Plans (Actual and Estimated) and the 3 ways in which they are presented (Textual, Graphical, and XML). Also discussed are Plan Guides.
episodes.title: Optimize Queries Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish exploring query optimization by looking at Dynamic Management Views and the 3 Hint types (JOIN, QUERY, and Table). Also covered are JOIN types and Nested Loops.
episodes.title: Optimize Queries Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss how SQL Server 2014 manages Transactions to ensure the database integrity. They explain how SQL 2014 uses Commits and Rollbacks to this end as well as the difference between Implicit and Explicit transactions. Also covered are the isolation levels.
episodes.title: Manage Transactions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie evaluate the use of row-based operations vs. the set-based operations. They explain when to use Cursors as well as the impact of Scalar User Defined Functions(UDFs). Also, they demonstrate combining multiple DML operations and using set-based logic rather than row-based logic.
episodes.title: Evaluate Different Operations

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss implementing errors and error handling in SQL Server 2014. They define and discuss the types of locks and their scope of use. They also look at implementing the TRY/CATCH/THROW functions and custom error reporting.
episodes.title: Implement Error Handling
